Award.AwardTitle: Dynamic network models: Entrance boundary and continuum scaling limits, condensation phenomena and probabilistic combinatorial optimization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The recent explosion in the amount of empirical network data, ranging from brain networks of interacting neurons, to the Internet, transportation, social networks, and other self-organized behavior, has stimulated vigorous activity in a multitude of fields, including biology, statistical physics, statistics, mathematics, and computer science to model and understand these systems. The aim of this research project is to develop systematic mathematical theory to understand dynamic networks: systems that evolve over time through probabilistic rules. The investigator plans to develop robust mathematical techniques to understand how macroscopic connectivity arises via microscopic interactions between agents in a network. One important direct application is whether a message or a disease is able to reach -- or at risk of reaching -- a significant fraction of the population of interest. Mathematical techniques used to understand such questions have unexpected connections to combinatorial optimization, where one is interested in designing optimal networks between individuals, particularly by considering an important concept known as the minimal spanning tree. The project will also explore swarm optimization algorithms (inspired by the collective behavior of simple individuals such as ants) and their ability to solve hard optimization problems via probabilistic interaction rules through stigmergy (where the network of interacting agents changes the underlying environment which then effects the interaction of the agents). An important component of the project is involvement of students at all levels, including the development of undergraduate research seminars and research projects.

Understanding the metric structure of the giant component and the critical scaling window in inhomogeneous random graph models has been daunting, yet for several decades the community of combinatorial probabilists has seen it as key to understanding more complicated strong disorder systems. The project aims to develop a unified set of tools through dynamic encoding of network models to understand the metric scaling of the internal structure of maximal components in the critical regime. The investigator plans to show convergence to continuum limiting objects based on tilted inhomogeneous continuum random trees and in particular to prove universality for many of the major families of random graph models. Scaling exponents of key susceptibility functions in the barely subcritical regime will be studied. The relation between metric structure of components in the critical regime and the entrance boundary of Markov processes such as the multiplicative coalescent will be explored. The entire program is the first step in understanding the minimal spanning tree on the giant component under strong disorder. These models have spawned a wide array of universality conjectures from statistical physics. The project will also study optimization algorithms and meta-heuristics inspired by reinforcing interacting particle systems and stigmergy, providing qualitative insights and quantitative predictions on hard models in probabilistic combinatorial optimization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We developed mathematical techniques to understand networks that change over time, including long range dependence of the system on the initial structure of the network. We studied the effect of change points (i.e. times when the rules governing the evolution of the network abruptly change) on the evolution of networks including macroscopic properties such as the degree distribution of the network.   Efficient and provably consistent estimators for change point detection were derived. Next we used mathematical techniques derived for change point detection to understand source detection problems on networks in particular estimating the initial seed that was the genesis of the network given only the topology of the network observed at one time point.  

Next we used dynamic network models as tools to understand objects such as single linkage clustering (alternatively the minimal spanning tree) on data with sparse relational structure. These objects are closely related to maximal connected components in critical percolation models, i.e. models where edges in the underlying network are deleted. We considered dynamic versions of such edge deletion and showed that this phenomenon on many different network models can be closely approximated by models first proposed in colloidal chemistry (in particular the multiplicative coalescent). We then showed that these maximal components with edges appropriately rescaled converge to limiting random compact fractals providing information on the geometry of such objects in the large network regime.   Finally we identified the scaling limits and geometry of the minimal spanning tree when the underlying network has a heavy tailed degree distribution.

In trying to understand phenomenon such as opinion dynamics or observed signals in brain scans, we studied general families of network time series described via interacting diffusions where the interactions are modulated via a (possibly dynamically changing) network structure; propagation of chaos results and functional central limit theorems were derived. Motivated by epidemiology,  we studied interacting particle systems such as the contact process on network models and  established necessary and sufficient conditions for an epidemic to occur (i.e. a positive density of the network to get infected).  

With regards to applications, we developed statistical methodology to reconstruct degree distribution of an underlying graph based on indirect sampling algorithms such as random walks. We collaborated with domain scientists in neuroscience and urban policy to apply the insights developed in the grant including constructing null models for weighted networks for community detection to analyze networks with an inherent self-loop propensity (e.g. commuting flows between counties where there is a strong propensity to live and work in the same county) and temporal weighted networks (e.g. bike share networks).
